before.translation[0].definitions[0].def: earlier than a particular event or action
before.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: I saw her a few days before she died.
before.translation[0].definitions[1].def: so that something does not or cannot happen
before.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Put that money somewhere safe before it gets stolen.
That dog ought to be destroyed before it attacks any more children.
Before I could say anything more, Holmes had rushed off towards the station.
before.translation[0].definitions[2].def: used to say that something happens after a period of time
before.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: It was several minutes before we realised what was happening.
It will be a while before we know the results.
before.translation[0].definitions[3].def: used to say that something must happen in order for something else to be possible
before.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: You have to pass a test before you can get a licence.
before.translation[0].definitions[4].def: used to warn someone that something bad will happen to them if they do not do something
before.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Get out before I call the police!
before.translation[0].definitions[5].def: used to emphasize that someone does not want to do something
before.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: She would die before she would admit she was wrong.
before.translation[0].note_box[0].items[: You use the present simple with before to talk about a future event Don’t use ‘will’ You say
I want to get home before it rains
before.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The new road should be completed before the end of the year.
Let’s meet at our house before the show.
We only got back from Scotland the day before yesterday (=two days ago).
Other students joined in the protest, and before long (=soon) there was a crowd of 200 or so.
Hugh arrived just five minutes before the ceremony.
five minutes/two hours etc before something
I usually take a shower before having my breakfast.
before.translation[1].definitions[1].def: ahead of someone or something else in a list or order
before.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: You were before me in the queue.
The files are in alphabetical order, so B1 comes before C1.
before.translation[1].definitions[2].def: used to say that something happens where it can be watched by people
before.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Italy will face Brazil this afternoon before a crowd of 100,000 spectators.
an actor who had performed before the Queen
before.translation[1].definitions[3].def: used to say that someone or something comes to be judged or considered by a person or group of people
before.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The proposal was put before the planning committee.
before.translation[1].definitions[4].def: used to say that one thing or person is considered more important than another
before.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: I put my wife and kids before anyone else.
In the air transport business, safety must always come before profit.
before.translation[1].definitions[5].def: in front of something or someone
before.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: The priest stood before the altar.
The sea stretched out before them.
before.translation[1].definitions[6].def: if one place is before another place on a road or journey, the first place is nearer to you than the second, so you will reach it first
before.translation[1].definitions[6].exa: The pub is 100 metres before the church on the right.
the last station before the Simplon Tunnel
before.translation[1].definitions[7].def: if there is a job or situation before you, you will have to do the job or face the situation
before.translation[1].definitions[7].exa: The task of emptying the house lay before us.
before.translation[1].definitions[8].def: if a period of time is before you, it is about to start and you can do what you want during it
before.translation[1].definitions[8].exa: We had a glorious summer afternoon before us to do as we pleased.
You have your whole life before you.
before.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: earlier than something or someone
She could read before she started school.
Do you want to have a shower before me?
prior to
before something happens
Please arrive at the airport two hours prior to departure.
by
no later than a particular time or date
The children are usually in bed by 9 o'clock.
We have to be out of our hotel room by 10 o'clock.
earlier
before now, or before the time you are talking about
I saw her earlier.
I had sent the letter earlier in the week.
previously
before now, or before a time in the past
He previously worked as an electrician.
The show starred a previously unknown actress called Jennifer Aniston.
in advance
before something happens – used especially when talking about the arrangements for something
Let me know in advance if you are going to be late.
The landlord wants three months’ rent in advance.
beforehand
before something happens, especially so that you are ready
I wish we had known about all this beforehand.
It’s always best to decide beforehand how much you want to pay.
before.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Haven’t I met you before somewhere?
Never before had he seen so many people starving.
She looked just the same as before.
before.translation[2].definitions[1].def: ahead of someone or something else
